statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: USC 89, California 70
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- With one 3-pointer after another, every bit of Gabe Pruitt's freshman timidity disappeared. When the final shot landed, he strutted back upcourt like a veteran -- and Southern California was well on the way to an impressive win. Pruitt hit five 3-pointers in the first half, and Jeff McMillan had 19 points and 10 rebounds to lead USC to its second road victory of the season, 89-70 over California on Saturday. Pruitt scored all 19 of his points before halftime, and Nick Young added 15 for the Trojans (11-15, 4-11), who certainly didn't look like the Pac-10's last-place team while overwhelming Cal for just their second win in eight games. Pruitt and Young picked apart the Golden Bears from outside as USC built a 15-point lead in the first half. McMillan and Gregg Guenther then scored inside while the Trojans gradually pulled away for their first win in Berkeley since 2001. "We showed what we really can do -- what we should have done before," Pruitt said. "We put together two halves. We didn't give up the second half, like we normally do. We kept playing hard, and Cal gave up in the second half." The Trojans split their Bay Area road games on the trip, but it could turn out to be a signature weekend for Pruitt, who hit seven 3-pointers and scored a career-high 23 points in Thursday's loss at Stanford. He already leads all Pac-10 freshmen in 3-pointers, and he's averaging nearly 13 points per game -- the highest average for a USC freshman since Harold Miner in 1990. "Before, there were jitters with me being young and college being the big thing," Pruitt said. "I was just trying to find my way through. I've got a lot of confidence now." The Trojans launched 19 3-pointers in the first half alone, hitting nine. Their repeated scores from outside silenced the fans at Haas Pavilion before many had even settled into their seats. Guenther finished with 12 points and eight rebounds, and Rory O'Neil had 11 points before fouling out. Pruitt also fouled out. In the final games of interim coach Jim Saia's tenure, USC has been aggressive from outside. The Trojans are 43-for-98 on 3-pointers in their last four games, but McMillan and Guenther also controlled the paint against Cal. "As far as keeping a lead and staying in it mentally, I think this is the best game of the year for us," McMillan said. "We already beat this team, and we felt we could beat them again." Rod Benson had 13 points and 10 rebounds for the Golden Bears (12-12, 5-9), who lost for the fourth time in five games -- and reached the lowest point yet in their disappointing season. Cal looked listless and unprepared in a loss to the bottom-dwelling Trojans, making countless unforced errors and playing terrible defense. Benson was among the team leaders who were incensed after the performance. "When you're getting seriously blown out, there's got to be some changes made," Benson said. "We've got to do something to change things. I don't care if I don't play at all in the next game. Let's get the right guys on the floor, and let's win some games. It's basically a low since I've been here, and that's got to change." Richard Midgley, the Bears' leading scorer, had his third straight miserable game, scoring nine points on 1-for-5 shooting and six free throws. He's 3-for-26 in his last three games. His teammates were no better. Starting guard Ayinde Ubaka had just two points until hitting a 3-pointer in the final minute -- and almost everybody played regrettable defense. "It's not a time to worry about where we are," Cal coach Ben Braun said. "It's a time to do something about it."
